text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service

Read and interpret this IRM in accordance with pertinent law, Government-wide regulations, Treasury Human Capital Directives and Issuances, Comptroller General Decisions, and Office of Personnel Management guidance, as relevant.

comply with the: a. 14 General Principles of Ethical Conduct for the Federal Employees (Document 9300) b. IRS Ethics Handbook (Document 12011) c. IRS Outside Employment and Business Activity Rules (Document 12011-A) This IRM supersedes the Human Capital Office memorandum HCO-06-0120-0003, Interim Guidance on Outside Employment Procedures, dated February 13, 2020.
AUDIENCE
All business units

and (
) Purpose: This IRM describes the process and maintenance of IRS Outside Employment (OE) requests and records to ensure compliance with
of the General Principles of Ethical Conduct covered in the Office of Government Ethics (OGE) Standards of Ethical Conduct (refer to links in IRM
, Related Resources). It contains procedures for requesting and receiving approval to perform permitted OE activities, distributing approved/disapproved requests, and annually updating OE records. (
) Audience: The policies, authorities, procedures, and instructions contained this IRM apply to all business units excluding contractors and Chief Counsel. (
) Policy Owner: The IRS Human Capital Officer (HCO). (
) Program Owner: The IRS HCO Policy and Audits (P&A) and Labor/Employee Relations and Negotiations (LERN) divisions. (
) Primary Stakeholders: The IRS HCO P&A, LERN and Human Resources Shared Services divisions. (

) Program Objectives: To ensure employees request approval to perform permitted OE activities, if appropriate, and to regularly remind employees they must not perform prohibited OE activities. Managers must timely review and approve/disapprove requests and annually update their employees’ approved records to comply with the IRS OE policy ( Document
-A ), and the tenth ethics principle covered in Document
, IRS Ethics Handbook, and Docu- ment
General Principles of Ethical Conduct. Refer to links in IRM
, Related Resources. (

of the Code of Federal Regulations (CFR),
CFR
describes the ethics principles established for federal government employees. (

) The tenth ethics principle states, “Employees shall not engage in outside em- ployment or activities, including seeking or negotiating for employment, that conﬂicts with official Government duties and responsibilities”. Refer to IRM
, Related Resources. (
) This IRM provides guidance to comply with the IRS Ethics Handbook ( Docu- ment
) and the IRS Outside Employment and Business Activity Rules ( Document
-A ; OE policy). Refer to IRM
, Related Resources. (
) Failure to comply with the OE policy, ethics rules, or related statutes and regu- lations, may result in action including discipline or removal from the IRS. (

Title 5 of the Code of Federal Regulations (CFR), 5 CFR 2635 describes the ethics principles established for federal government employees.
Failure to comply with the OE policy, ethics rules, or related statutes and regu- lations, may result in action including discipline or removal from the IRS.

The IRS Human Capital Officer is the executive responsible for this IRM and Servicewide policy for outside employment.
) The HCO Office of HR Strategy’s Policy and Audits (P&A) division is respon- sible for developing policy and publishing content in this IRM. (

) The HCO Office of HR Operations’ (OHRO) Labor/Employee Relations and Negotiations division collaborates with P&A on the content of this IRM, ensures adherence to these IRM procedures, and assists managers with addressing disciplining employees who violate the policy/procedures. (
) The HCO OHRO HR Shared Services division is responsible for the online outside employment system. (
) IRS managers and employees are responsible for complying with this IRM the referenced policies. (
) This section provides responsibilities for: a. Business Units (organization) b. Business Unit POCs (BUPOCs) c. Managers d. Employees e. Deputy Ethics Official (

) Each business unit is responsible for designating an Outside Employment Business Unit POC (BUPOC) to monitor their organization’s OE records to ensure compliance and to serve as a representative on the IRS OE team. (
) Business Units are responsible for: a. Ensuring managers comply with the

b. Serving as the business unit’s contact to answer questions about OE resources, using the automated OES and reviewing internal business presentations or communications. c. Serving as the liaison between the business unit and the IRS OE POC. d. Attending POC meetings and completing associated actions. e. Running OES reports to monitor OE compliance and sharing reports managers and/or POCs to assist with their compliance monitoring. f. Monitoring their organization’s OES records to ensure:
Requests are processed within
workdays. Refer to IRM

Duplicate records are deleted (moved to history). g. Identifying discrepancies (compliance issues) in OE records, coordinating appropriate action and conﬁrming completion. h. Contacting the IRS OE POC to resolve OES issues. (
) The employee’s i. Immediate (ﬁrst-level) manager serves as the Recommending Official ii. Second-level manager serves as the Approving Official. (
) Managers must: a. Submit a BEARS request for access to their organization’s records in OES. Refer to IRM
, Access to OES. b. Read this IRM, the OE policy, and the IRS Ethics Handbook to ensure the OE or activity complies with the regulations and IRS policies. For example, it:
) is not prohibited by statute, regulation, the OGE, Treasury standards, or IRS policies and
) does not conﬂict with the employee’s IRS duties. Note: Refer to links in I RM

, Related Resources. c. Ask their manager or the Deputy Ethics Official (DEO) if they need help determining whether the employee’s requested OE activity is permissible and/or if it conﬂicts with the employee’s IRS duties. Refer to IRM
I, Contact Information. d. Add their employee’s OE request to the OES if it is submitted on Form

, Outside Employment or Business Activity Request. Note: Once added to OES, the system automatically sends an email message to managers to notify them of actions needed. This ex- cludes email notices for the annual review requirements. Refer to IRM
, Annual Review Process in OES. e. Read and act on the email notices from the Totally Automated Personnel System (TAPS)/OES. For example, review and approve/disapprove new requests within
workdays. Refer to IRM
, Control Standards. f. Prepare a written statement to the employee citing the reason(s) for dis- approving a request and include the reason in OES in Remarks. Note: Remarks ﬁeld is limited to
characters. Abbreviate if needed. Employment

g. Distribute and ﬁle approved and disapproved requests. Refer to IRM

, Document Distribution. h. Contact their BUPOC with questions about records, reports or using the OES. i. Hold annual reviews with employees who have approved requests to cuss the status of their OE and update the OES record with the date the review was held. j. Remind employees of the OE policy (e.g., the requirement to submit re- quests for approval in advance, to notify you if they stop performing the OE). (
) Employees must: a. Read this IRM, the OE policy, and the IRS Ethics Handbook (refer to links in IRM
, Related Resources) to ensure the OE or activity they are interested in pursuing complies with the regulations and IRS policies. For example, it
) is not prohibited by statute, regulation, the OGE, Treasury standards, or IRS policies, and

) does not conﬂict with the employee’s IRS duties. b. Ask their manager, or the DEO for help, if needed, in determining if the desired OE activity is permitted or prohibited. c. Submit a request for approval at least
workdays prior to accepting starting the OE or business activity. d. Not perform the OE or business activity:
) during IRS duty hours Note: On occasion, with the exception of sick leave, OE may be performed in an approved leave or leave without pay status.
) at their assigned post of duty, temporary work location, or during duty hours at an IRS-approved telework site;
) on Treasury or IRS property; and
) using any government property. e. Notify their manager if:
) their IRS position (e.g., occupational series or position description) duties change or will be changing;
) their OE position or duties change or will be changing; and
) they stop performing the approved OE. f. Submit a new request if their IRS or OE position or duties change, and they want to continue performing the previously approved activity. Ethics Official (

, Request for Opinion from Deputy Ethics Official. c. Does not answer questions about using the IRS OES. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

Management (

) This IRM provides guidance on the OE program. The HCO P&A and LERN divisions gauge the effectiveness of this guidance by considering feedback from customers and stakeholders as part of the review process for all Internal Management Documents. During this process, IRM sections are added, revised, or removed. Changes are usually based on statutory and/or regulatory changes. (

) Program Reports and Effectiveness: Managers and/or POCs pull OES reports to monitor compliance. The IRS OE POC sends detailed TAPS OES reports to the BUPOCs to assist managers with ensuring compliance and tifying issues or emerging trends. Program management measures trends the timeliness of processing OE requests, as well as the annual update of approved OES requests to ensure compliance with this ethics principle and IRS OE policy. Controls (

) To ensure instruction in this IRM remains current and compliant with regula- tions, the policy and program owners will annually review this manual for procedural, organizational, or operational changes and accurate instruction ganizational, or operational changes and accurate instruction. Standards (
) The control methods include: a. Separation of Duties: The OES requires approval by two levels of agement for all OE requests. b. Approval Process: All OE requests, including those submitted on Form

, go through a two-step review/approval process in the OES. c. Annual Review: Managers, POCs and the IRS OE POC regularly test internal controls to conﬁrm employees timely submit requests, and managers timely process new requests, timely hold annual reviews and update approved OES records annually. (
) The goal of the OE policy is to: a. timely process (review, initial, date, approve/disapprove)
% of new OE requests in the OES, and b. timely hold the annual review and annually update
% of the approved requests in the OES. (
) The OE policy, IRM
, and the National Agreement require approval/ disapproval of OE requests within
workdays of the date the employee their request. Note: IRS will increase approval/denial compliance in the OE system by
% year, eventually achieving
% timeliness. (

The OE policy requires managers to hold annual reviews with employees who have approved requests and to update their record in the OES.
Note: IRS will increase annual review compliance by 10% each year, eventually accomplishing 85% of annual reviews timely.
) Outside Employment (OE) – paid or unpaid employment or business activities, performed by IRS employees outside their IRS employment duties. (

) Outside Employment System (OES) – An online system located in the “Main Menu” of the IRS’s TAPS/Single Entry Time Reporting (SETR) application that stores OE requests and records. Employees use this tool to submit new requests and managers use it to process requests and annually update records. (
) OES Reviewing Official - employee’s immediate manager. (
) OES Approving Official - employee’s second-level manager. (

) BUPOC – the business unit’s point of contact for their organization’s managers and employees. They answer questions about using the OES and assist managers who are responsible for ensuring compliance with the OE policy. Resources (

This IRM establishes the process for submitting requests for approval to perform permitted OE activities that require approval.
) Refer to Document
-A , IRS Outside Employment and Business Activity Rules and Document
IRS Ethics Handbook to determine if the desired OE activity is permitted or prohibited. (
) For bargaining unit employees (BU) covered by negotiated agreements, negotiated agreements related to this IRM. If any of these instructions conﬂict with BU provisions in Document
, IRS-NTEU National Agreement, the agreement prevails.
) Employment (OES) (
) In
, managers and employees began using the automated system, which maintains all IRS OE requests in a centralized online source. The system resides in the same menu as timekeeping (SETR) on IRS’s TAPS.
) to OES (

) All OE requests must be processed in the Outside Employment System Employees who input their time in TAPS/SETR automatically have OES access. Managers and others responsible for ensuring OE compliance must submit a BEARS request as described below.
) Employee Access (
) Employees who input their time in TAPS/SETR can add their request to the OES (do not submit a BEARS request). (
) Bargaining unit employees who do not input their time in TAPS/SETR may submit their request on Form
. Management then adds the request to OES.
) Supervisor Access (
) Managers must submit a BEARS request to process (review, initial/date and approve/disapprove) OE requests, to add requests submitted on Form

and to annually update their employees’ approved records in the OES. a. Sign into the BEARS site. b. Search Application Name to ﬁnd TAPS/SETR (TAPS). c. Click Modify (to the right). d. In the Special Instructions ﬁeld, state as appropriate: i. Immediate Managers – “Requesting access to the Outside Employment System for Organizational (Org) code(s) XX-XX-XXXXX”. ii. Second-level or above Managers – “Requesting FAMILY access to Outside Employment System for Organizational (Org) code(s) XX-XX- XXXXX”. e. Contact the BUPOC or your timekeeping POC for help with your organi- zation’s code(s). (
) A new BEARS request must be submitted whenever the manager’s or their employee’s org code(s) change (for example, when manager is promoted or changes offices).
) POC/Administrativ
ccess (

) BUPOCs and administrative personnel who serve as their manager’s POC must submit a BEARS request for access to their organization’s OES records. a. Sign into the BEARS site. b. Search Application Name to ﬁnd TAPS/SETR (TAPS). c. Click Modify (to the right). Outside Employment

XX
XXXXX”. ii. Second
level or above Managers – “Requesting FAMILY access to the Outside Employment System for Organizational (Org) code(s) XX
XX
XXXXX”. Contact the BUPOC or your timekeeping POC for help with your organi
zation’s code(s).
BUPOCs and administrative personnel who serve as their manager’s POC must submit a BEARS request for access to their organization’s OES records.

In the Special Instructions ﬁeld, state: “As the Outside Employment POC for [my manager, the business unit], I’m requesting [FAMILY] access to the Outside Employment System for Organizational (Org) code (s) XX
XX
XXXXX”.

for [my manager, the business unit], I’m requesting [FAMILY] access to the Outside Employment System for Organizational (Org) code (s) XX- XX-XXXXX”. Note: Add the word FAMILY if you need access to all codes within an area. For example, the Level
org code for HCO OHRO is
and the Level org code for LERN is

). If the POC is responsible for all of HCO, they would request FAMILY access to all codes assigned to Org Code
If the POC is only responsible for the LERN office in HCO, they would request FAMILY access to all codes assigned to Org Code
e. Contact your SETR (timekeeping) POC for help with your business organizational code(s). (
) Submit a new BEARS request when a change in Organizational codes occurs (for example, when a POC changes groups). (
) Read and review the OE policy ( Document
-A ) and the IRS Ethics book ( Document
) to ensure the pursued outside employment or activity is permitted (not prohibited) and does not conﬂict with your IRS duties. Refer to links in IRM
, Related Resources. (
) Submit requests at least
workdays before accepting or starting a permitted OE position. (

) Add your request to the OES as follows: a. Login to TAPS/SETR (where timekeeping is located). b. Click “Outside Employment” (an option in the Main Menu). c. Click “Add Request or Query Record.” d. Click “ADD” before completing any ﬁeld. Note: “OE Description” ﬁeld is limited to

characters. e. Once all ﬁelds in the “Requester” section are completed, click “Submit” (bottom of screen). Note: The greyed-out boxes are automatically completed with the employ- ee’s HRConnect data after clicking “Submit”. f. If successfully added, a message displays, at the top, stating: “Request added. First and second-level managers will receive email notices to process the pending request.” g. If a required ﬁeld is incomplete or contains an error, a message displays at the top of the screen. h. ) The pre-approval requirement will be waived in the event of a furlough or shutdown. However, upon Return-To-Duty status, employees must submit request if they intend to continue the OE activity. (

) The manager/employee data, including email addresses, in the OE System pulled from HRConnect. If the data in HRConnect/OES is not accurate, process a personnel action to correct it. (
) Once adding a request to the OES is successful, TAPS automatically sends emails to managers advising them to act. (
) Managers have the right to request more information from the employee to properly evaluate and approve/disapprove OE requests. (

) The employee’s immediate and second-level managers must review and approve all requests in the OES. Note: Exception: Employees without a second-level manager (e.g., Deputy Com- missioner for Operations Support), their immediate manager serves as the reviewing and approving/disapproving official. ) After the immediate manager approves the request in OES, the system an email notice to the second-level manager to approve/disapprove. (
) After the second-level manager processes the request in OES, the system automatically send an email notice to the immediate manager to distribute record. Refer to IRM

) When disapproving a request, management is responsible for preparing a written statement to the employee citing the reason(s) for disapproval. The Employment

) The written authorization of the IRS Commissioner is required for requests appear on behalf of any taxpayer, as a representative, before any Federal, State, or local governmental agency, in an action involving a tax matter, as stated in the OE policy. (
) Complete Form
for this type of request. (

) A memo must be prepared by the employee’s immediate and second-level managers, addressed to the IRS Commissioner, through the IRS OE POC, scribing management’s detailed assessment of the request (e.g., any conﬂict with the employee’s IRS duties and the requested representational role, any concerns, any guidance requested and received from the Deputy Ethics [if received, attach to memo]). (
) Send the memo and any attachments to the IRS OE POC through your BUPOC. Please refer to the IRS HCO Outside Employment website for contact information. (
) Allow a minimum of
workdays to process. Distribution (

) After management approves/disapproves the OE request, the record must printed from OES (Click: Query, Submit, locate employee record, OE Record, Print) and distributed as follows: a. OPF Copy : Attach the OE record to an encrypted email and send it to the employee’s Official Personnel Folder (OPF) at OPF.Con.Site@irs.gov with the subject “Outside Employment Record – ﬁle in OPF”. All requests, approved and disapproved, must be ﬁled in the employee’s OPF. Do redact the employee’s social security number (SSN). b. Drop File Copy : Redact SSN and ﬁle in the employee’s non- performance ﬁle (Drop File). c. Employee Copy : Redact SSN and provide a copy to the employee. (
) Distribution does not occur when management holds the annual review or when moving records to history after an employee stops the OE activity. IRS Position - When to Request (
) Once approval is received, any changes in the employee’s IRS position and/or duties, or changes in their OE position and/or duties, require a new request and approval. (

) Managers must annually review and update approved requests in the OES conﬁrm the information remains accurate, does not conﬂict with the employee’s current IRS position/duties, and to determine if the approval should continue, be rescinded, stop or if the employee needs to submit a new request. (Stopping) Employment (
) Employees must promptly notify their immediate manager when they stop forming OE. (
) When an employee stops their approved OE activity, management must update the OES record, and move it to history (archive).

When an employee stops their approved OE activity, management must update the OES record, and move it to history (archive).

) . Deleted records are “Historic”, inactive and cannot be revised. OE records must be up to date prior to deleting, as follows: a. Log into TAPS/SETR (where timekeeping is located). b. Click “Outside Employment” (an option in the Main Menu). c. Choose

st option, “Add Request or Query Record.” d. Click “Query” and “Submit” to display all records. e. Click “ID” number (blue hyperlink, to the left of the record needing action). f. Ensure ﬁelds are accurate and complete. g. Click “Back to Result” (at bottom of screen). h. Click the trash can (on right). i. Conﬁrm you want to move record to History. (
) Approved OE requests must be reviewed every
months to ensure the mation remains accurate, does not conﬂict with the employee’s current IRS duties, and to determine if the approval should continue. (
) Management must monitor the due date with OES reports and calendar reminders as the TAPS OES will not generate reminders. (
) Managers must annually update the OES with the date they held the mandatory annual review with their employee. (

) Managers must annually review and update approved requests in the OES conﬁrm the information remains accurate, does not conﬂict with the employee’s current IRS position/duties, and to determine if the approval should continue, stop or if the employee needs to submit a new request. (
) Managers and POCs should pull OES reports to monitor timely completion the Annual Review and to project deadlines to hold the annual review. (
) The Annual Review Date (last ﬁeld on the OE record) is the only ﬁeld updated annually. (

) The Annual Review Date in the OES reﬂects the date of the annual review cussion with the employee. Update the OES as follows: a. Log into TAPS/SETR (where timekeeping is located). b. Click on “Outside Employment” (an option in the Main Menu). c. Choose

st option, “Add Request or Query Record”. d. On the next screen, click “Query”, then scroll to the bottom and click “Submit”. This displays all records corresponding with the user’s request in BEARS. Review the list and click on the record(s) needing to be updated. Note: You can “Query” individual records by entering either the employ- ee’s organizational code, their last name, OR their SEID, and click “Submit.” e. In the list display, click the “ID” number for the record you are updating (blue hyperlink, to the left). f. Review the record to conﬁrm the “Date Reviewed” (column heading) is less than
months old. If the employee signed the request less than months ago, the ﬁeld can be blank. Employment

st option, “Add Request or Query Record”. d. On the next screen, click “Query”, then scroll to the bottom and click “Submit”. This displays all records corresponding with the user’s request in BEARS. Review the list and click on the record(s) needing to be updated.

g. Go to the Annual Review Date ﬁeld, input the date the review was held and click “Submit” (bottom of screen). h. Schedule a calendar reminder, in approximately
months, to hold next annual review and update the OES record. Note: The TAPS OES system does not send email reminders to conduct the annual review and update the Annual Review Date in OES. Review (
) The OE policy and program owners will annually review the policy and proce- dures in this manual. (

) The OES reports can help managers and POCs certify new requests are timely approved/disapproved and the required Annual Reviews are timely updated in OES. These reports should be run at least monthly to monitor records. (
) Login to OES (an option in the Main Menu in TAPS/SETR). (
) Select Outside Employment Report. (
) From the drop-down menu, select Organization. (
) Type the Org Code levels needed (xx-xx-xxxxx). (First two digits for the business unit, the ﬁrst four digits for the division level, or all nine digits for individual team). (
) Select Retrieve to view records with the option to print to PDF, or Excel to save and download the data to your computer. (
) Review the following columns: a. Supervisor’s Signature Date – monitor to ensure immediate manager initials/dates within
workdays. b. Approving Official’s Signature Date – monitor to ensure second-level manager initials/dates within
workdays. c. Annual Review Date – monitor to ensure it is less than
months old. Note: Annual Review Date can be blank if employee signed the request less than
months ago. (
) The HCO OE website, found in the Related Resources section above, step- by-step resources for managers and POCs to pull real-time reports the OES. Misconduct (

) As stated in the IRS Ethics Handbook, allegations of ethics violations (such performing a prohibited Outside Employment activity or working an OE activity without approval) must be reported to your manager or to the Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administrative (TIGTA). Employees can contact TIGTA via email at Complaints@tigta.treas.gov or by phone at
